fields.description:
CLC has crashed 4 times in the last 15 days.  Each time, the following error shows up in the cloud-output.log:

{noformat}
2013-07-14 21:10:18 ERROR | java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: unable to create new native thread
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: unable to create new native thread
        at java.lang.Thread.start0(Native Method)
        at java.lang.Thread.start(Thread.java:693)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.addWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:949)
...
{noformat}

To bring the CLC back, the eucalyptus-cloud process has to be restarted.  Once thats done, the instances all went into _pending_ state that were previously in a _running_ state.  In order to get the instances to show in the correct state, the eucalyptus-cc process had to be restarted.   The following error was seen in the cloud-error.log:

*cloud-error.log*
{noformat}
Sun Jul 14 21:03:58 2013 ERROR [AsyncRequest:Eucalyptus.cluster:ClusterConfiguration:arn:euca:eucalyptus:sanmateo-1b:cluster:cc-smeuca01/.class java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker#277] [com.eucalyptus.util.async.AsyncRequest$2.call(AsyncRequest.java):232] java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: unable to create new native thread
Sun Jul 14 21:04:58 2013 ERROR [AsyncRequest:Eucalyptus.cluster:ClusterConfiguration:arn:euca:eucalyptus:sanmateo-1b:cluster:cc-smeuca01/.class java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker#276] [com.eucalyptus.util.async.AsyncRequest$2.call(AsyncRequest.java):232] java.lang.RuntimeException: org.jboss.netty.handler.timeout.ReadTimeoutException
{noformat}

Out of curiosity, does ELB need to be activated when running a 3.3 Cloud?  Currently ELB isn't registered or _ENABLED_.  Would this cause the issues seen above?
fields.summary: Multiple CLC Crashes Due to  java.lang.OutOfMemoryError

The jsch stuff is used to connect to the SAN and issue commands using SSH.

The basic pattern for a command in 3.3.0 is:
connect
send command
run 'whois'
parse output based on user name returned by 'whois' (a known name) as the end-delimiter.
close session.

Possible causes of all those open sessions:
* Changes in Equallogic output such that parsing breaks.
* Incomplete output sent to channel by EQ such that the SC doesn't see the final delimiter it looks for
* Incorrect configuration for EQ stacking such that the IP configured does not return expected output (or any output) for at least one command.

Solutions:
* The jsch connections should be timed out after a relatively short period. Say, 20 seconds. This should be a configurable parameter to handle cases where perhaps the SAN or network are slow etc. But, regardless of the actual time, the session should be terminated after some timeout even if the command has not fully returned.

Summary: The Customers CLC was crashing every 3 or 4 days with an java.lang.OutOfMemoryError. 
In the heap dump 329.4MB out a total 464.9MB memory in the eucalyptus_cloud process being 
referenced by java.lang.Thread. In the same heap dump we are seeing a total of 5271 out of

This leak happens with out any instances or volumes being created all you need to do to reproduce 
this have a SAN configured and the vmwarebroker running.

Solution: The BufferedReader was not being closed in ShellSessionManager.runTask(final AbstractSANTask task).
I added a finally clause that closes both the reader and the writer.

2) Attach JConsole remotely use the URL ${YOUR_CLC_HOST_IP}:8772 (remotely or locally)
3) In JConsole select the Threads Tab.
4) In the Threads Tab enter 'Shell' in the filter textbox
5) a) Without the fix in the jconsole Threads window you will see Shell threads collecting and 
      not being cleaned up and the Number of threads continue to grow.
   b) With the fix in the jconsole Threads window you will see the shell threads being cleaned up, this means the 
      BufferedReader is being closed and the Thread is being released for garbage collection. The Number of threads 
      should stabilize and not continue to grow.
